nodes.text: A security’s beta is the expected percentage change in the return of the security for a 1% change in the return of the market portfolio. That is, beta represents the amount by which risks that affect the overall market are amplified or dampened in a given stock or investment. As demonstrated in

, securities whose returns tend to move one for one with the market on average have a beta of one. Securities that tend to move more when the market moves have higher betas, while those that move less have lower betas.
For example, let’s look at Cisco’s stock.

shows the monthly returns for Cisco and the monthly returns for the S&P 500 from January 2014 through December 2018. Note the overall tendency for Cisco to have a high return when the market is up and a low return when the market is down. Indeed, Cisco tends to move in the same direction as the market, but its movements are larger. The pattern suggests that Cisco’s beta is greater than one.

metadata.caption: Note that Cisco’s returns tend to move in the same direction but farther than those of the S&P 500.

config.caption: Note that Cisco’s returns tend to move in the same direction but farther than those of the S&P 500.
config.activityTitle: Monthly Excess Returns for Cisco Stock and for the S&P 500, January 2014 through December 2018

nodes.text: We can see Cisco’s sensitivity to the market even more clearly by plotting Cisco’s return as a function of the S&P 500 return, as shown in
. Each point in this figure represents the returns of Cisco and the S&P 500 for one of the months in
. For example, in October 2015, Cisco’s return was 10.7% and the S&P 500’s was 8.5%.

metadata.caption: Beta corresponds to the slope of the best-fitting line. Beta measures the expected change in Cisco’s return per 1% change in the market’s return. Deviations from the best-fitting line, such as in June 2015, correspond to diversifiable, unsystematic risk.

config.caption: Beta corresponds to the slope of the best-fitting line. Beta measures the expected change in Cisco’s return per 1% change in the market’s return. Deviations from the best-fitting line, such as in June 2015, correspond to diversifiable, unsystematic risk.
config.activityTitle: Scatter Plot of Monthly Returns for Cisco Versus the S&P 500, January 2014 through December 2018

nodes.text: As the scatter plot makes clear, Cisco’s returns have a positive correlation with the market: Cisco tends to be up when the market is up, and vice versa. In practice, we use linear regression to estimate the relation between Cisco’s returns and the market’s return. The output of the linear regression analysis is the best-fitting line that represents the historical relation between the stock and the market. The slope of this line is our estimate of its beta. That slope tells us how much, on average, the stock’s return changes for a 1% change in the market’s return.
Formally, the beta of an investment is defined as:

data.mathML: <math alttext="" display="block" altimg="../images/mm_altmath_64.png" altimg-height="72" altimg-width="551"><mrow><msub><mi>β</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mover><mover><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SD</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>×</mo><mtext mathvariant="italic">Corr</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">Mkt</mtext></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">SD</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">Mkt</mtext></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow><mo stretchy="true">︷</mo></mover><mrow><mtext>Volatility of </mtext><mi>i</mi><mtext> that iscommon with the market</mtext></mrow></mover><mo>=</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">Covariance</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>i</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">Mkt</mtext></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mrow><mtext>Var</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mrow><mtext mathvariant="italic">Mkt</mtext></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mfrac></mstyle></mrow></math>

nodes.text: , the best-fitting line shows that a 1% change in the market’s return corresponds to about a 1.2% change in Cisco’s return. That is, Cisco’s return moves about 1.2 times the overall market’s movement, and so Cisco’s beta is about 1.2.
To fully understand this result, recall that beta measures the systematic, market risk of a security. The best-fitting line in

captures the components of a security’s returns that can be explained by market-risk factors. In any individual month, the security’s returns will be higher or lower than the best-fitting line. Such deviations from the best-fitting line result from risk that is not related to the market as a whole. This risk is diversifiable risk that averages out in a large portfolio.

But what is the beta of the market portfolio? Imagine plotting the returns of the S&P 500 against themselves. You would have a line with a slope of one and no deviations from that line. Thus, the beta of the market portfolio is 1. What about a risk-free investment? Because the risk-free return is the return earned on a Treasury bond and is therefore known in advance, it has no volatility and hence no correlation with the market. Therefore, the beta of the risk-free investment is 0.
Using Excel: Calculating a Stock’s Beta
Enter or import the historical returns for the stock and the S&P 500 into Excel.
Next, use the LINEST function in Excel.
The output will appear in the cell. In this case, the beta is 1.15 in the screenshot above.

Beta corresponds to the slope of the best-fitting line. Beta measures the expected change in Cisco’s return per 1% change in the market’s return. Deviations from the best-fitting line, such as in June 2015, correspond to diversifiable, unsystematic risk.
